blocks.text: Again, $a = \sqrt{1 - \sin^{2} \theta}$.  If the connecting rod is long compared with the crank, $r$ is small and $\sin^{2} \theta$ still smaller, so that our method of approximation can be applied to the expansion of the bracket, if we note that \[ \cos \theta = 1 - \frac{1}{2} \sin^{2} \theta, \text{ very nearly.} \]

blocks.caption: Velocity and Acceleration of Piston
blocks.description: The figure illustrates the motion of a piston, showing the displacement and position relations involved. This is important for understanding how angular movement translates to linear displacement.

blocks.text: Let $AB = $ displacement of the piston from its in-dead-centre position = $AE - AE'$ = $AD - BD - OD.$ We cannot differentiate this expression, so we write \[ \frac{dAB}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(AD - BD - OD) = \frac{dAD}{dt} - \frac{dBD}{dt} - \frac{dOD}{dt}. \] Hence \[ \frac{dAB}{dt} = r \frac{d\theta}{dt} \cos \theta - 0 - 0 = r \frac{d\theta}{dt} \cos \theta. \] or \[ v = \frac{dAB}{dt} = r \frac{d\theta}{dt} \cos \theta = \frac{2\pi r}{T} \cos \theta, \text{ where } T = \text{ period of rotation.} \]
